partial_orders.reason: Both edits involve the 'user' option in the same class. Edit 0 adds the 'user' option to the user_options list, while Edit 1 removes the conditional addition of 'user' to user_options and adds 'user' directly to the boolean_options list. These edits reference the exact same 'user' option symbol and appear to be part of a single refactoring task to unconditionally include the 'user' option. The changed lines in both edits explicitly reference the same 'user' option, making them mechanically linked - after adding 'user' to user_options unconditionally, the next logical step is to also add it to boolean_options unconditionally and remove the conditional logic.

Both edits perform identical structural changes: removing the same conditional check 'if sys.version > "2.6":' and unindenting the same block of code that imports site, manipulates site.USER_BASE, imports build_ext, and sets build_ext.USER_BASE. The changes are mirrored - both remove the version check and make the same imports and assignments unconditional. This represents a uniform refactoring pattern applied to two related methods (setUp and tearDown) that handle the same resources. The edits reference the exact same symbols (site, old_user_base, build_ext.USER_BASE) and apply identical before→after transformations to the same type of syntactic construct (conditional blocks). Either edit could be made first as both are independent applications of the same refactoring pattern.
